segments.text: Jim Wilson and I shared a room at 410 Emerson in the home of Mrs. Scotty Duncan Forbes.
If that's not an appropriate name for a splendid Presbyterian lady of Scottish descent, I've never heard one.
She and her ancient cat fossil were special and unforgettable.
That year included continuing the Naval Reserve and the expectation of active duty beginning in June of
More importantly, I was trying to lay the groundwork for what I assumed would be a lifetime a record as a graduate student that would affect the rest of my life.
The courses were demanding, but the faculty was kind and sensitive.
And so when I left to go to report to active duty in Charleston, South Carolina, the Naval Receiving Station on June 15, I looked back on a year which I thought had been comparatively successful.
And I certainly
expected to return to Rice in the fall of 1956.
When we landed at the receiving station in Charleston and made our way to the receiving station, as we entered the gate
of that impressively large establishment, a big black Marine greeted me in a memorable manner.
Come on in these gates, boy.
You're in the Navy now.
Your ass belongs to me.
at the first gathering of all of us, quote, transients, a first-class petty officer that we soon learned was nicknamed Ipana because of the obvious distinctive lack
of toothpaste use, which left his teeth unmistakably colored.
Dash told us not to unpack, make many phone calls, or do anything because we would all be gone within two weeks.
In the meantime,
We were assigned to temporary task as the cleanup crew for the receiving station.
Sweeping, mopping, cleaning out showers, commodes.
And then I got assigned to the trash truck helping lift
55 gallon barrels, which were then used as trash barrels.
Because there'd been a lot of late spring rain, the barrels had collected a lot of water.
So as we lifted them up, the holes in the bottom of the barrel gave us each a fragrant shower.
All of the men that arrived with me were soon gone, and I was a sole survivor.
Finally, after about three weeks, I very hesitantly made my way to the desk of the chief warrant personnel officer.
told him my name and the fact that I had been there longer than anticipated and wondered if there was something I should do.
He looked up, called me by name, and then sent a fright through my brain as he mentioned
as he said, oh, we have lost your service record.
We've been wondering where you were, period, quote.
Having heard the rumor that the worst thing that could happen to an enlisted man was the loss of his record, I worried about my fate.
Until he smiled and said, but we found it.
It had fallen between two file boxes, between two filing cabinets.
Then he inquired, are you really a college graduate?
Have you been doing graduate work?
Proudly, I responded in the affirmative way, and he said, well, then we're going to keep you here because we're shorthanded.
He then pointed me toward the information and education office where I would spend the following two years worrying that they must have somehow made a mistake
because they gave me an assignment for which I had preparation and an interest.
That post included helping to prepare dischargees for their post service education
whether returning to high school or going to college, to help administer the quarterly printed tests for promotion for all enlisted personnel, and joining with educational efforts
both on the base and in the greater Charleston area.
The most interesting of those assignments came late in the spring of 1956 before the United States officially transferred to Japan two, quote, old World War II destroyers,
dash the first warships which the victorious allies allowed the Japanese to operate after World War II.
My task was to give a crash course in conversational English to the Japanese enlisted men, and I soon learned that they were the brightest, most determined students I had ever encountered.

One of the highlights, one of the enjoyable highlights of those two years resulted from a brief mention in the Charleston paper that the backfield coach of the Cooper River Blue Devils, a football team composed of students from
North Charleston and Chicora, C-H-I-C-O-R-A, high schools, the two high schools nearest the base, had just accepted appointment as head coach at another high school as the 1955 season was beginning.
The Blue Devil head coach, Hibby, H-I-B-B-Y, Hibby Ayoub, A-Y-O-U-B,
expressed regret in the article that at such a late date he could not hire an assistant coach and he really needed a backfield coach.
Forgetting how little real athletic experience I had had in two years of high school and two years of two years each in high school and college,
I went to see Coach Ayoub and volunteered to assist him for free, dash, if he could get me off the base at 3 o'clock, a reward for which I would have done almost anything.
That delightful experience helped me become acquainted with a wide variety of
people in Charleston and an emotional attachment with some very promising young men whose careers have certainly been marked with distinction.
Another key event in those years
was attendance at the Southern Historical Association annual convention in Columbia, South Carolina in the fall of 1955.
At that meeting, I reinforced connection to some of the
Instructors that had been so helpful.
And that my first year at Rice.
And they introduced me to a new.
Member of their group.
Who would be joining them in the fall of?
Frank E Vandiver.
Dr. Vandiver, the child prodigy son of a mathematics faculty member at the University of Texas, already had earned a fine reputation as a very young but talented Civil War scholar.

Thus, I thought about working with him because I remembered that in the first year at Rice, the most memorable course was a year-long seminar on Civil War and Reconstruction guided by William B. Hesseltine, H-E-S-S-E-L-T-I-N-E, one of the most respected
preparers of doctoral students in the profession.
Dr. Hesseltine, a senior member of the faculty at the University of Wisconsin, had a long list of students he had prepared for true leadership in history.
In the course of the seminar, he gave us much care in how to write prose, how to maximize time on the, quote, time on the road, doing research, and

suggested that when we picked out a dissertation advisor, if possible, select someone who was comparatively young, whose reputation would grow, and to whom we would be able to turn for advice, counsel, and job recommendations.
for decades to come.
Dr. Vandiver seemed like such an individual, so I planned to work with him.
As the spring of 1956
came and I looked forward to leaving Navy duty.
I began to think about dissertation topic and talked with Dr. Vandiver about
writing on the role of Presbyterians in the South during the Civil War, their breakaway from their northern counterparts, and then the creation of an entirely separate denomination.
He gave his general approval to that as a worthy task.
And again, with Heseltine advice.
As a guide.
Began to search for the primary location.
Of materials.
Relating to.
That topic.
That search led to the historical foundation of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, located at Montreat, M-O-N-T-R-E-A-T, North Carolina.
Further inquiry?
identified the availability of a little single bed, quote, room, quote, in the basement of Geneva Hall, a student dormitory at the summer conference grounds for Southern Presbyterians
at Montree for the fee of a dollar a night, a sum which seemed affordable.
Paragraph, so after a quick trip home to Orange to leave my sea bag and participation in the marriage of some Austin College friends in Temple,
I hurried back to Montreat and what I thought was a stylish light blue and white 1954 Ford Victoria quote, with white leatherette interior.
While unpacking that vehicle at Geneva Hall,
late in the day, I inquired of Bill Dean who would be residing in the next accommodation in Geneva Hall about a place to eat.
When I suggested the
Montreat Dining Hall he shook his head and recommended a place two buildings away which was a frame structure operated by a
retired furniture store owner from Jacksonville, Florida, whose wife had inherited what was called Bridges Lodge, a very pleasant structure.
He mentioned that
the foreign missionary appointees and other missionaries on their sabbatical ate there.
When I asked him why we should go there instead of the cafeteria,
He said the food was very good, to which I responded, check.
That it was comparatively low in price, check, check.
And that if we would wait and go to the second table, they put all the food on the table, and we could join then

in eating that delightful blend with the owners of Bridges Lodge, the cook, and there were three pretty girls from some little town in central North Carolina that joined, that were working there for the summer.

At my second meal in Bridges Lodge, breakfast the next morning, a great deal of teasing centered on one of the three young ladies who had, after her evening chores, gone down the hallway to shower and then discovered that her
two girls from her town had hidden her clothes and the towels while she was in the shower.
In some manner,
Her embarrassment and the attractiveness of her smile during the teasing caught my attention.
An attachment which has now lasted for 44 years.
Within a few weeks I asked her, Margaret Joanne Phillips, Jo by name, to go to the movie in Asheville and quickly our
Romance warmed.
By the end of the summer, I took her home to meet her family, to spend a week in meeting her family in central North Carolina before returning to Rice.
A complicating factor in this relationship was that we shared the birthday of March 18,
But there was an eight-year difference between my birth year in 1931 and hers in 1939.
So while I returned for my second year of graduate work at Rice, she finished high school.
I sent her the money to fly to Texas.
Oh, back up.
Luckily for me, the Southern Association

Southern Historical Association was hosted by Duke University that fall and met in Durham, North Carolina, only 20 miles east of Mebane, M-E-B-A-N-E. That gave me a good opportunity to see her again that fall.
One evening,
During that brief visit, after I returned to the hotel, to the George Washington Duke Hotel in downtown Durham, and entered a somewhat disorganized
Lobby crowded with.
Outdated newspapers.
Tobacco smoke.
An evidence of a group of historians.
Unfor.
Undeniable evidence of historians.
Spare time.
Two senior.
Hotel Bellman asked me some questions, including, quote, what kind of guys are these men?
I responded, historians.
Then they wondered, what do they do?
Do they do any work?
Yes, sir, they teach.
Why do you ask?
And in summary.
He mentioned that they had been.
Talking about this group and agreed upon three generalities.
The first of which was.
Quote.
Day de why day is the lightest tippers we've ever had.
Number two, they tells the corniest jokes we've ever heard.
And number three, they talk more about women and do less with them than anybody that stayed in this hotel, period, quote.
As Christmas approached, I sent the money for an airplane ticket to Joe.
so she could meet my family during the Christmas holidays.
I met her in New Orleans and drove back to Orange and also took her to see Rice, meet Mrs. Forbes, and then that night parked on the beach
at Galveston.
I proposed to her, and the next evening, she accepted.
A few weeks later, when I came back to Orange on a weekend near the end of my stay, I told Mother that I would need her help
with addresses and she said what for and I told her that I was that Joe and I were getting married on June 15.
Her positive response and dad's smile were unforgettable signs of their acceptance.
A
warm feeling that lasts forever.
So as I worked on Southern Presbyterians that year, wedding preparations were also in high priority as I went to North Carolina during spring break.
and we prepared for the wedding.
That event on June 15 at the First Presbyterian Church in Mebane, June 15, was by today's standards rather modest.
The young bride and groom-to-be bought the flowers and arranged them themselves at the
A friend of Joe's mother cooked the wedding cake, baked the wedding cake, and her sister Doris provided the music.
Some of the Cooper River Blue Devils came to be in the wedding.
And we went, we drove, before we drove to Williamsburg, Virginia for our wedding trip.
Then came back to Montreat and spent the rest of the summer doing research before coming to Houston and renting a small apartment
and I can't remember the name of the street.
Jo enrolled at the University of Houston as an English major and took almost a full-time load each semester.
Her schedule being limited only by our finances,
and the time it took for her to get to and from the campus since we only had one vehicle.
Finances, our income at that time included the GI Bill, about $150 a month, and an assistantship at Rice
an arrangement which I did not know existed when I applied for admission in 1954.
That total of about $300 a month paid our rent and allowed us to save some money.
By our third year there, we were back at 410 Emerson
where Joe cooked for Mrs. Forbes and the two of us and kept house because Mrs. Forbes was beginning to become a little more frail.
As that year ended, as the 1958-59 year ended,
we began to look for permanent employment.
The first opportunity was to teach four introductory courses each semester at the junior college, which then
operated downtown at night on the second floor of the central Houston YMCA.
Compensation for that effort from 7 to 10 o'clock Monday through Thursday night would have been $2,400 for the nine-month year.
Not an attractive sum.
Then I was contacted about filling a one-year vacancy at Texas Southern, then the comparatively new, primarily black institution just north of the University
of Houston when I visited with the dean of that institution.
And he told me the pay would be $2,800 a month, $2,800 a year, and patted me on the back as he chuckled.
you can be our token white boy for next year.
A third possibility came at McNeese State College in Lake Charles, Louisiana, less than an hour east of Orange, where
I applied.
And apparently was a finalist.
Where the pay would have been about.
3600 a year.
Thankfully.
Another phone call changed.
everything for us.
But first, a step backward.
In the fall of 1958, one day in Dr. Vandiver's office, I overheard...
I... Paul...
Our conversation was interrupted by a phone call from College Station, Texas.
During that conversation, I understood that Ralph Steen, the then deeply respected, the highly respected
head of the history department at A&M, whose record as a historian of Texas was unequaled, had just been selected as the new president at Stephen F. Austin State College in Nacogdoches.
He was calling Dr. Vandiver to ask if he had anyone who could come up
and accept responsibility for his American history courses on that short notice.
Dr. Vandiver recommended me and then hand me the phone.
Soon, I expressed fear that since I had not yet passed my PhD preliminary exams,
it might be imprudent for me to accept that temporary task, and so I respectfully declined Dr. Steen's offer.
A few months later, Dr. Steen's successor as department head, Joseph Milton Nance, also called Vandiver.

Again, Dr. Vandiver handed me the phone, and Dr. Nance told me that they were looking for someone to fill a one-year vacancy because one of their department members would be on leave at the University of Houston for the 1959-60 academic year.
The task would be teaching four survey sections in American history.
And would I be interested?
I told him that I would be.
He inquired about when I could come up for an interview.
A quick glance at my watch led to the response that it was then 10 o'clock.
Would 2 o'clock that afternoon be too late?
With a bit of lightness in his voice, he accepted that suggestion and I drove up.
We went to Nagel Hall and I entered a new world.
Dr. Nance, a comparatively compact man,
of medium height quickly demonstrated that he was serious and thorough in his task and thorough in his research.
He already had obtained all the appropriate information about me.
And within less than two hours, he told me that the job would be four sections of American history numbered in the Aggie system 105 and 106.

with the reconstruction as the dividing, the period of reconstruction as the dividing point, that it would be a one-year assignment because John Hill was on leave at the University of Houston and was expected to return the following year.
The pay would be $550 a month for nine months or
He told me that he would get a letter to me soon, and when that epistle came, it required that I respond in writing within 48 hours, which I very gratefully and proudly did.
And we began to make our plans for a year in Aggieland.
Another Aggie link came quickly.
And once more, Dr. Vandiver was a key helper.
when the dean of Shriner College, S-C-H-R-E-I-N-E-R, Shriner Institute in Kerrville, called to seek a summer, a teacher for the summer session only.
This vacancy was created
when an old Austin college buddy, Ed Wilburn, was going to be on leave finishing his master's degree.
A few telephones and letters were exchanged with
Dean H. C. Weir, W-E-I-R, who was Dean of the Institute and in fact directed its actions on the daily basis.
By this time, Joe was expecting our first child and as we drove out for the interview with Dean Weir,
The obstetrician who was assisting, who was caring for Joe, recommended that we stop every hour for her to quote stretch her legs and relax from sitting in the car.

One of those stops, we made one of those stops just inside the cattle guard of a ranch west of Austin where she took off her shoes and cooled her feet in the water standing underneath a little bridge.
Quickly, a pickup came our way, a pickup truck came our way, and the man told us that we'd have to
move because we were on, we were intruding in the pasture of the LBJ Ranch and that we should not invade the privacy of Senator Johnson.
The weeks at Shriner were totally enjoyable.
